summary: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogenic -proteobacterium. it belongs to the genus Neisseria that also includes the human pathogen Neisseria meningitidis. it is the causative agent of gonorrhoea, one of the most common sexually transmitted infections. a better understanding of N. gonorrhoeae infection and virulence could facilitate new treatments of gonorrhoea. novel immunogenic proteins could provide first indications of crucial proteins involved in gonococcal pathogenicity. another application for immunogenic proteins is the development of vaccines. the identification of immunogenic proteins is performed by 2D-PAGE and immunoblot followed by mass spectrometry [22–25], by time and labour consuming expression of the proteome and screening on nitrocellulose membranes [26], or recently by microarray technique [27–29]. however, all of these methods have certain disadvantages. phage display of antigens may avoid these limitations. the phenotype (protein fragments) is coupled with the genotype (corresponding gene fragments) by using polyclonal antibodies, patient or animal sera, immunogenic oligopeptides are selected in a panning procedure. this technology allows for the discovery of immunogenic proteins independent from pathogen cultivation, thus also identifying proteins only expressed in the patient (in vivo host pathogen context) the phage displayed oligopeptides were mapped to the obtained models. the obtained immunogenic proteins could serve as promising candidates for the further clarification of gonococcal infection and for the development of effective agents against N. gonorrhoeae. clones randomly picked from three different libraries (A) and from the phage packaged library (B), Lane 25 Empty pHORF3 vector control without insert, Lane 26 No template control, M Size ladder. panning and screening of oligopeptide phage A polyclonal rabbit antibody to N. gonorrhoeae was used for the panning rounds. oligopeptides isolated by phage display and proteins identified by BLAST were dismissed after screening due to low signal intensities in ELISA. Previously identified as immunogenic in Neisseria genus or found in outer membrane vesicle vaccines. NGO1043* hypothetical protein 2 160/217 11.41 NMB1468 Periplasm Yes [51] NGO1429 molecular chaperon DnaK 10 67–325 68.86 NMB0554 Cytoplasm Yes [25,48] NGO1577 outer membrane protein PIII 6 115–274 25.54 NMB0382 Outer membrane Yes [48,52] NGO1634* hypothetical protein, putative phage associated protein 2 97/133 21 all identified oligopeptides which were not described as immunogenic in literature before were produced as full-length proteins. three proteins known to have an immunogenic character in N. meningitidis with localisations predicted as non-cytoplasmic were expressed in full-length proteins. expressed full-length antigens were validated by ELISA using three commercially available polyclonal antibodies from different immunisations. proteins NGO0170, NGO0326, 2 NGO0326, 3 NGO0451, 4 NGO0564 (+ control), 5 NGO0642, 6 NGO0777, 7 NGO0916, 8 NGO1043, 9 NGO1500 (- control), 10 NGO1634, 11 NGO1656, 12 NGO1657, the cut-off was set to fourfold of the signal of the negative control BB0069. three polyclonal rabbit antibodies against N. gonorrhoeae from different immunisations were used. the identified oligopeptides isolated by phage display were then mapped to the protein models in monomeric shape. for multimeric proteins the identified oligopeptide is located at the C-terminal end of the protein spanning over three -helices and two -sheets. the closest structural homologue to NGO0326 was a homo hexamer of Lysteria monocytogenes. NGO1634 and NGO1796 exhibit oligopeptides in the middle of the protein. all models were checked for their reliability by QMEAN [64] the cloned libraries had an in-frame insert ratio of approximately 5%. in-frame insert rate was increased to 70% after Hyperphage packaging. clones were randomly picked from three different libraries. eight oligopeptides exhibited no homologies to known antigens. one clone carried parts of two genes—NGO1656 and NGO1657—the last 92 bp of NGO1657. both genes were chosen to further characterise the immunogenic character of their encoded proteins. NMB1320 Cytoplasm Yes [47] NGO0592 trigger factor 3 115–208 48.37 NMB1313 Cytoplasm Yes [48] NGO0642* tRNA pseudouridine synthase B 1 262 33.39 NMB1374 Cytoplasm No - NGO0777* DNA-binding protein Hu 1 100 9.38 NMB1230 Cytoplasm No - NGO0916* dihydrolipoamide succinyltransferase NGO2095 chaperonin 60 kDa subunit 11 67–301 57.35 NMB1972 Cytoplasm Yes [25,48] NGO2139 genome-derived Neisserial antigen 1946 1 327 31.34 NMB1946 Cytoplasmic membrane Yes [56,57] The number of inserts found during screenings with different insert sizes are listed. proteins with apparent molecular mass of 11 kDa and 13 kDa were detected by SDS-PAGE. the latter corresponding to NGO1043 plus leader sequence, the smaller band corresponding to NGO1043 alone. proteins NGO0564, NGO1043, NGO1656 and NGO1852 were detected with high signals in ELISA. proteins NGO0170, NGO0326, NGO0642, NGO0777, NGO1634 and NGO1796 had high signals above the cut-off. a real-time PCR was conducted with the three cDNAs and negative controls. the lowest RIN value for the three isolated RNAs was 8.9. the closest structural homologue to NGO0326 was a homo hexamer of Lysteria monocytogenes. oligopeptides from NGO0642 and NGO0777 are identified in the N-terminal part of the proteins while NGO1634 and NGO1796 exhibit oligopeptides. immunoproteome studies of N. gonorrhoeae have not been available yet. polyclonal rabbit antibodies to N. gonorrhoeae were applied for panning. displayed oligopeptide is located at the C-terminal end of the protein. the closest homologous structure identified by I-TASSER was a putative metal-chelate type ABC transporter of Haemophilus influenza [62]. the identified oligopeptide is accessible by antibodies raised against it. a deletion of the homologue of NGO0326 in N. meningitidis leads to a differentiated expression of 369 ORFs [73] this resulted in an altered bacterial growth rate and reduced adherence to epithelial cells. the closest homologous structure identified by I-TASSER was the Hfq protein of L. monocytogenes. NGO0777 was shown to be upregulated in a gonococcal deletion mutant lacking a dam replacing gene. it is involved in DNA repair in certain stress situations which could also be the case in cell adhesion or infection. a real-time PCR analysis was performed to validate the presence of mRNA coding for this protein. osome recycling factor (rrf) is involved in the recycling of ribosomes upon translation. it showed signal intensities above fourfold of the cut-off of the negative control. studies with an E. coli homologue showed that it is essential for bacterial growth and a possible target for novel antibacterial treatments. NGO1656 and NGO1657 were expressed as full-length proteins. one selected clone contained DNA sequences of both proteins. the last 92 bp of NGO1657, a non-coding part of 48 bp and 131 bp of NGO1656. homologue NMB1468 was described as an immunogenic protein in N. meningitidis. it was strongly bound by a polyclonal anti-N. gonorrhoeae rabbit antibody in ELISA validating its immunogenic character for N. gonorrhoeae FA1090. several periplasmic ABC transporters comparable to NGO0170 were found to be surface-exposed in N. meningitidis [87,88]. homologues of NGO0326, NGO0564, NGO0592, NGO0777, NGO0916, NGO0983, NGO2095 and NGO2139 were also detected in outer membrane fractions. further investigation of NGO1634 could provide detailed information as to the protein’s potential function, localization and structure. virulence-associated proteins were identified such as NGO0326 and NGO1577 increasing the likelihood of discovering virulence-associated factors among the identified proteins. a goat anti-rabbit IgG (Fc-specific, Biomol 611–1103 Lot#29341) was used as capture antibody for the panning procedure. three different antibodies against N. gonorrhoeae from separate immunisations and pools of individuals were deployed for the validation of full-length immunogenic proteins. DNA fragments with sizes from 100 to 1000 bp were extracted from an agarose gel. 700 ng of fragmented DNA were then ligated into the PmeI digested pHORF3 vector (1000 ng). three transformations per ligation into E. coli TOP10F’ (Invitrogen) by electroporation. phage particles were precipitated with 1/5 volume 20% (w/v) polyethylene glycol (PEG6000)/2.5 M NaCl solution for 3 h on ice with gentle shaking. phage particles were then pelleted for 1 h at 10,000 x g and resuspended in 10 mL phage dilution buffer (10 mM TrisHCl pH 7.5, 20 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA) the DNA was separated and analysed by capillary electrophoresis. plasmid DNA was sequenced with primers used for colony PCR. wells were coated with 150 L of a goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody. 150 L of amplified phage of previous panning round were used for the second and third round. each panning round the steps were increased by ten with a total number of three panning steps. infected cells were harvested by centrifugation for 10 min at 3250 x g. the remaining pellet was resuspended in 30 mL 2x YT-AK and incubated at 30°C and 250 rpm overnight for phage production. bacterial cells were then pelleted by centrifugation for 20 min at 3250 x g. the bacteria were pelleted by centrifugation at 3250 x g for 10 min. pellets were resuspended in 175 L/well 2x YT-AK. precipitated phage particles were pelleted by centrifugation at 3250 x g for 1 h. coli TOP10F’ lysate and 1 x 1010 cfu/mL Hyperphage per mL of the dilution and preincubated for 2 h. the preincubated antibody was incubated on the captured phage particles for 2 h and detected by a goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (HRP) for 1.5 h. d vector pET21A+ (NdeI/NotI) or pET21A+pelB (NheI/NotI) positive clones were identified by colony proteins 200 mL 2x YT-GA broth were inoculated with 10 mL overnight culture. the agarose settled by gravity flow and washed with 10 mM, 30 mM and 50 mM imidazole (50 mM Na2HPO4, 300 mM NaCl, 8 M urea, pH 8). the wells were then incubated at RT with the preincubated antibody for 2 h. and rabbit IgGs were detected with goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody conjugated to HRP (1:20,000) the reaction was stopped by adding 100 L 1 N sulphuric acid. the absorbance was measured at 450 nm using a microplate reader (BMG Labtech) a part of the gene of NGO0715 (glucose-6-phosphate 1-dehydrogenase) was applied as positive control. the reaction was set-up with Maxima SYBR Green qPCR Master Mix (2x) using the following program: 95°C 10 min, 40 cycles of 95°C 15 s, 50°C 30 s, 72°C 30 s with a single data acquisition after the elongation step. signal peptides were predicted using SignalP 4.1 [95]. all models were selected based upon their C-score. a C-score with a higher value represents a model with a high confidence. a mouse anti-M13/fd/F1/pVIII antibody was used for capturing of oligopeptide phage particles during the screening ELISA. a colorimetric readout for ELISA assays was achieved with a polyclonal goat secondary antibody to rabbit IgG conjugated to horseradish peroxidase. the genomic DNA was isolated by phenol chloroform extraction or GeneJET Genomic DNA Purification Kit (Thermo Scientific K phage particles were pelleted for 1 h at 10,000 x g and resuspended in 10 mL phage dilution buffer (10 mM TrisHCl pH 7.5, 20 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA) oligopeptide phages were resuspended in 1 mL phage dilution buffer. bacterial cells were removed by centrifugation for 1 min at 16.000 x g. plasmid DNA was sequenced with primers used for colony PCR. the wells were washed thrice with PBS supplemented with 0.1% Tween20 (PBST) and blocked for 1 h with PBST supplemented with 2% milk powder (2% MPBST) for each panning well, two wells of a Maxi-Sorp W 96 well plate (Nunc) were coated with 200 L 5 x 1010 cfu Hyperphage in PBS at 4°C overnight and blocked with 2% MPBST for 1 uted phages of both wells were combined and 10 L were used for titration. the remaining 390 L were used to infect 20 mL of an E. coli TOP10F’ culture grown to an OD600 of 0.5. the cells were incubated for 30 min at 37°C and harvested by centrifugation for 10 min at 3250 x g. atant were incubated for 1 h with 6 mL PEG/NaCl on ice with slight shaking on a rocker, followed by centrifugation at 6000 x g for 1 h at 4°C. the pellets were resuspended in 500 L phage dilution buffer (10 mM TrisHCl pH 7.5, 20 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA), centrifuged in a precipitated phage particles were pelleted by centrifugation at 3250 x g for 1 h. phage containing supernatants stored in a new plate at 4°C. 100 L of 250 ng/mL antibody in PBS were coated over-night. the gene of the negative control BB0069 was amplified with genomic DNA from Borrelia burgdorferi B31. the amplified genes were digested with two restriction enzymes. RNA was isolated by using RNAprotect Bacteria Reagent (Qiagen 76506) and RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen 74104) a second DNA digestion was used to eliminate residual DNA contaminations. the RNA integrity number (RIN) lies within the range of 0 to 10. the primers which were used for real-time PCR are listed in Table 3. a melting curve was recorded starting at 95°C with 0.05°C/s slope decreasing to 45°C. a melting curve was recorded starting at 95°C with 0.05°C/s slope decreasing to 45°C.
